title: [K-12] Concrete-to-Abstract Teaching Method Workshop for Elementary Mathematics Concept Formation: Integrated Approach to Computation, Graphs, and Formulas for Strengthening Geometry and Algebra Problem-Solving Skills

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of basic mathematical concepts (arithmetic, geometry, algebra) and basic awareness of educational settings, simple formula calculation skills, fundamental graph interpretation abilities (bar charts, line graphs)
context.additional_context: A practice-centered course for pre-service/in-service teachers to strengthen math instructional competency. Emphasizes teaching methods using manipulatives to support elementary students' abstract thinking development and problem-solving assessment techniques. Covers concrete instructional strategies for geometry (measuring sides/angles of shapes) and algebra (solving linear equations and analyzing variable relationships).

learning_goals: Explain the step-by-step application principles of the concrete-to-abstract teaching method (manipulation → representation → abstraction) and apply them to designing lessons utilizing formulas and graphs (coordinate planes, function graphs) for math problem-solving

Present ≥3 instructional tools (tangrams, geoboards) and digital tools (GeoGebra, Desmos, graphing calculators) that aid concept understanding in geometry/algebra domains and analyze actual classroom cases

Within one week, learners orally present a developed instructional model through project-based assessment (3 math problem-solving projects: equation solving, geometric measurement, pattern analysis) to ≥3 peers and receive an "Excellent" rating in ≥1 of 2 feedback criteria (creativity, practicality). Special emphasis is placed on variable relationship analysis in equation solving, measurement accuracy in geometric measurement, and sequence pattern identification in pattern analysis
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
